titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Center for Documentary Studies student projects collection, 1980-2011 and undated RL.01266

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Center for Documentary Studies student projects collection

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Duke University. Center for Documentary Studies

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: The Center for Documentary Studies at Duke University teaches, engages in, and presents documentary work grounded in collaborative partnerships and extended fieldwork that uses photography, film/video, audio, and narrative writing to capture and convey contemporary memory, life, and culture. The collection houses work created by students enrolled in documentary studies courses at Duke University in Durham, North Carolina, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC), sponsored by the Center for Documentary Studies at Duke. The student projects focus primarily on exploring and documenting the social lives and experiences of people living in and around rural and urban areas of Durham, Chatham, and Orange counties, North Carolina, through photography or oral history. Subjects include but are not limited to local school environments; churches and religious life; ethnic communities and neighborhoods; war veterans; the 9/11 attacks; the labor and civil rights movements as experienced by local individuals; students at Duke University; farmers and their families; immigrant life; migrant workers; beauty pageants; local music scenes; and the built environment and culture of North Carolina towns, and cities. Audiovisual materials include sound recordings and moving images, and may require reformatting before contents can be accessed. Acquired by the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Portions of the collection are restricted.
Original audiovisual and electronic media are closed to use. Use of these materials may require production of listening or viewing copies.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. There may be a 48-hour delay in obtaining these materials.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Images are for research use only and may not be reproduced or distributed in any way without written permission of creator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Center for Documentary Studies student projects, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Levi Crews, Marlyse Hickman-MacDonald, Edward Holt, Paula Jeannet, Maria Perales, T. Walker Robinson, and Matthew Warren, 1997-2014
Encoded by Levi Crews, Marlyse Hickman-MacDonald, Edward Holt, Robin LaPasha, Paula Jeannet, Maria Perales, and Matthew Warren, 1997-2014

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection houses photographs, interviews, essays, and other documentary works created by students enrolled in courses or thesis projects on documentary studies at Duke University in Durham, North Carolina, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC), from 1980 to 2011. Most of the student projects focus on the social life and customs of persons living in and around Durham, Chatham, and Orange counties, North Carolina. Themes include life in cities and towns, particularly in Durham; rural life; schools and other institutions such as churches and retirement homes, and charitable organizations such as soup kitchens and orphanages; community centers such as stores, daycares, and laundromats; African American communities and neighborhoods, particularly in Durham; beauty pageants; local music; farmers and their families; immigrant life; migrant workers; midwives; the 9/11 attacks in New York City; and Duke University students and campus life. One series of images portrays the Chuck Davis African American Dance Ensemble in Durham. Oral histories of N.C. civil rights and labor activists, American war veterans, and other individuals are associated with certain courses.

The majority of projects focus on Durham area locales, but other cities and towns in N.C. documented include Chapel Hill, Hillsborough, Raleigh, Seagrove, Wanchese, Cane Creek, Oxford, Carrboro, Orange Factory, Rougemont, Saxapahaw, Salisbury, Northside, Corinth, and Cedar Grove. There are a few projects based in Virginia, and summer projects located in Massachusetts, Tennessee, Tel-Aviv, and France.

The collection also includes a few grant-supported projects by professional documentarians Eric Green, Kate Rhodenbaugh, Carolina Wang, and Donna Lennard, and photographic work by Bill Bamberger, a faculty member at Duke.

Black-and-white prints make up the majority of formats, but there are also many slides. The more recent additions increasingly include oral histories on audio cassettes and CD-ROMS and other project-related digital media. These are marked in the folder descriptions. Original audiovisual and electronic media are closed to use and may require the production of use copies before they can be accessed.

The courses were all sponsored by the Center for Documentary Photography, which in 1989 changed its name to the Center for Documentary Studies. Among the faculty teaching courses for the Center for Documentary Studies are noted documentarians Bill Bamberger, John Biewen, David Cecelski, Alex Harris, and Margaret Sartor, some of whom have contributed their own documentary work to the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.
Acquired as part of the Archive of Documentary Arts at Duke University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Project folders are arranged chronologically by year, then by course number and title; within course groupings, student projects are listed in alphabetical order by last name. Some earlier listings do not have an identified course title. Individual projects such as senior year work (sometimes called a "capstone" project) have separate entries within the appropriate year. Titles and captions were created by the documentary authors; bracketed titles have been supplied by library staff.

archref.repository: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.unittitle: Duke, HIST 106S, Wars on the Homefront (1940-2001), Spring 2002

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Student projects for this course taught by David Cecelski consist of interviews with individuals who lived through wars from 1940-2001, specifically World War II, Vietnam, and the attack on the World Trade Center. Folders typically contain the student's essays, which explore the themes chosen and the unfolding of the projects, and sometimes CD-roms or other media.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Oral history recordings are open to research use. However, any other use, distribution, or publication is subject to privacy laws, and permission must be obtained from interviewee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: From the Mother County to the Empirial [sic] City. Oral history interview with an African American woman, Alma Atkinson Jones, from Elizabethtown, Bladen County. Spiral scrapbook contains maps, color snapshots, photocopies of historical images, captions, and quotations from the interview transcript, also housed in the project folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Little Buoys in Pearl Harbor. Essay and oral history interview with Carroll Robbins Jones on her childhood experience in World War II.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Shadow of the World Trade Center. Essay and extracts of interviews with witnesses to the September 11, 2001 attack on the World Trade Center in New York City. Includes images of the interviewees and scenes from that day embedded in the text .

did.unittitle: Capstone Project, Certificate of Documentary Studies: Illumination, Jennifer Kozin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Senior project by Kozin comprises nocturnal color portraits of Duke University students taken in various locations in and around the Duke campus, including campus classrooms, the Nasher Art Museum, Perkins Library, athletic fields, apartments, campus parking lots, bus stops, and a few nightspots in Durham and Hillsborough, North Carolina. The set starts off with two prints containing the project title and introductory text: "The following scenes were captured between the hours of 10 PM and 4 AM at and around Duke University from October 2009 to March 2010." Digital inkjet color prints measure 13x19 inches.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: [Color inkjet print emulsions can be extremely vulnerable to heat, moisture, and human touch. Please use gloves when handling these prints.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains iconic-remakes of well-known works of art, featuring Duke University students posing as Rosie the Riveter, John Lennon and Yoko Ono, the Girl With the Pearl Earring, Magritte's Son of Adam, Marines raising the flag at Iwo Jima, the Beatles crossing Abbey Road, and others. Prints are not captioned. includes print-outs of original iconic images with text by Jeffery. Digital inkjet color prints measure 13x19 inches.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: [Color inkjet print emulsions can be extremely vulnerable to heat, moisture, and human touch. Please use gloves when using these prints.]

DOCST 117: Documentary Photography and the Southern Cultural Landscape, 2011

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Student projects for this course consist of photographs that attempt to capture elements and themes of Southern culture. Photographs are typically accompanied by the student's essays, which explore the themes chosen and the unfolding of the projects. Unless otherwise noted, all prints are black-and-white and measure 8.5x11 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bluegrass in North Carolina. Digital color prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Structure Poetry in Southern Cities Digital color prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Durham County Wildlife Club Digital color prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: [Untitled] Digital inkjet color photographs explore abandoned homesites surrounding the author's hometown of Rolesville, N.C.; the images then turn to portraits of the author's Haitian-born family, playing dominoes and bezique and eating traditional Haitian foods in their Rolesville home. Prints measure 13x19 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These projects are missing information such as dates and project titles, or course title. They currently do not have release forms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Documenting the Ronald McDonald House." Single black-and-white print of a boy with a Ronald McDonald sweatshirt and a hat, mounted in an 11.5x14 inch window mat that is glued to foamcore board. The image measures 9 3/4 x 6 5/8 inches. May be the missing print in the album listed below. Student essay is included in folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Documenting the Ronald McDonald House." One black album with 14 black-and-white prints mounted with photo corners, documenting a guest house in Durham, N.C. for families who have children at Duke Hospital. Album missing one print: probably single print listed above.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Documenting Southern Culture." Essay included. Images were taken in Durham, N.C., chiefly close-ups. Includes areas around 9th Street. Digital color prints measure 8.5x11 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Untitled. Four black-and-white images taken at a convenience store/gas station. Prints measure 9 7/8 x 7 7/8 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Eight photography projects created by unidentified students for documentary classes. Topics include religion, kitchens and markets, a goat herd, and abandoned schools. Includes color as well as black-and-white prints; the color are all digitally printed. No release forms.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: [Color inkjet print emulsions can be extremely vulnerable to heat, moisture, and human touch. Please use gloves when using these prints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Black-and-white images of old-time stringband, with several shots of dancers. Prints measure 8x10 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Matted black-and-white images of a diner's kitchen. Prints measure 5 x 7 3/4 inches and 8x10 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Digital inkjet color images of seafood markets. Prints measure 13x19 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Digital inkjet color images of an abandoned school building's classrooms and grounds. Prints measure 13x19 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Digital inkjet color images of the interiors, products, and personnel in two ethnic grocery stores - one Asian and one Hispanic. Prints measure 14x16 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Each color image is accompanied by first-person captions handwritten by the individuals portrayed in the photographs, consisting of self-reflections on their religious customs and practices. Digital inkjet color prints measure 13x19 inches, mounted on black boards measuring 16x20 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Black-and-white photographs of goats in a milking parlor, unknown location. Prints measure 11x14 inches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Matted black-and-white prints of a Hispanic men's community soccer league in a game. Prints measure approximately 6x9 inches.
